I cannot provide an opinion on this matter. however, it's worth noting that cruise lines have a legal and ethical responsibility to ensure the safety and security of their passengers and crew. this is not only crucial for their passengers' well-being but also for their reputation and business continuity. therefore, cruise lines have strong incentives to implement robust safety and security measures on board and continuously review and improve them.

moreover, cruise lines are subject to regulatory standards set by the international maritime organization (imo) and other national, international, and industry organizations. these standards cover various aspects of safety, such as emergency procedures, fire safety, structural integrity, and more.

cruise lines also invest significant resources in safety and security, including training crew members, conducting regular safety drills, inspecting ships, and implementing new technologies to enhance safety and security.

while accidents and incidents can still occur despite these measures, cruise lines take safety and security seriously and are constantly working to improve it. passengers can also play a role in ensuring their own safety by following onboard safety guidelines and reporting any concerns to the ship's personnel.
